item.description:
What deters wrongdoing?   Fear of God or legal sanction?  Or phrased another way:  A year in prison or an eternity in Hell?   Or perhaps the deterrent is unconscious  and expressed in a process of karmic correction and reincarnation that edges consciousness towards greater enlightenment.

Or is right behavior guided by something altogether different?   Perhaps higher consciousness is its own reward? Do we need the motivational lure of Nirvana, the absolute detachment that makes future incarnations no longer necessary? For my part, I think higher consciousness would always seek to reincarnate so that it might further advance consciousness through teaching and good deeds. Is Nirvana actually a paradoxical attachment to detachment?!   Can it not be argued that the only true detachment is pure dedication to the good, because attachment to good is also the truest form of detachment because it distracts desire from anything other than that which promotes good.

To summarize, might it not be said that the concept of Nirvana is a paradoxical attachment to detachment and, therefore, is a form of attachment.  However, with equal paradoxicality, the attachment to promoting and inspiring good is the truest form of detachment.  

Admittedly, I still have a hangover from our previous meeting.  As with that meeting, this meeting is equally East and West.  Let’s have a discussion about what really motivates and drives right conduct.   What is really good?   And what's really bad?   And don't forget the in-between.

This discussion is co-sponsored with the Eastern Philosophy Group.  To simplify RSVPs, those who are members of both groups should RSVP that you are "Going" with one of them, but not both.
